Using EJAM

Source: vignettes/0_webapp.Rmd
0_webapp.Rmd

EJAM and EJScreen websites

EJAM itself is not an app running on a public website. EJScreen will be able to leverage EJAM’s technology to provide public access to batches of reports, and will be able to do rapid multi-site analysis in a future update. EPA is working to integrate EJAM’s new toolkit into EJScreen’s public screening and mapping web application, as a way to enable these features as soon as possible. A web app was being tested for internal use at EPA as of early 2024.

R/RStudio users launching a web app

If you use R/RStudio, you also can use EJAM through a web-based UI on your own computer. You first need to install the EJAM R package and datasets as explained in Installing the EJAM R package.

Once EJAM is installed (and you have access to the datasets needed), you can launch the local web app from RStudio as follows:

library(EJAM)
run_app()

Note this is different than running a simple shiny app that is not also a package via the golem package. You should use the EJAM package function run_app() not shiny::runApp().

Note that the web app (e.g., launched locally) handles loading datasets and indexing blocks, assuming you have access to the server that stores those datasets as a pins board, so you would not have to download datasets manually or do indexing manually if launching the EJAM app locally. You can also download the datasets and store them locally. You do need the packages installed that EJAM relies on, as listed in the DESCRIPTION file, including the ones not on CRAN, notably EJAMejscreenapi and EJAMbatch.summarizer.
